titleStmt.title: Despatch from Albert Bushnell to William M. Evarts, September 20, 1879

bibl.title: Despatch from Albert Bushnell to William M. Evarts, September 20, 1879
Despatches from United States Consuls in Gaboon, 1856-1888 T-466

text.body:
<div1 xml:lang="en" type="document"
<pb facs="20170615_144312" Sir,
As the period for which I have remained leave of *unclear from the *unclear* Commercial Agency at Gaboon Equatorial West Africa, will soon expire; I hasten to inform the Bureau Department that i have been seriously ill during the last few make.
I am noe convaleseent, and expect to go to New York in a day or two, for business adivice of the report is favorable Mr. Bushwell and myself piur[ose sailing October eleventh for Liverport one route for Gaboon, I will inform you of our final decision at the earliest day practicable.
I have recently received a despatch from Ban. U.T Murphy, who was life of verge of the Commercial Agency informing one that *unclear after departure he has been denied. <pb facs="20170615_144316"
the privilege of flying the flag, because the Government at Paris, had not been officially informed of the reestablishment of the Commercial Agency, after its temporary discontinance. I return as Commercial Agent, or as Consul; it will be necessary for the Government at Paris, to be officially informed of the fact, and an Exequitable solicited.
Permit me to add, new forms will be needed, and also flags. As soon as the question of my returning in October is decided I shall have the honor of making definite requests to the Department.
I have the honor to be, Sir;
Most Respectfully, Your obedient Servant Albert, Bushwell U.S. Coml. Agent.
